{"label":"Title: "Disfluency rates in conversation: Effects of age, relationship, topic, role, and gender"

Authors: Arnold, J. E., Tanenhaus, M. K., Altmann, R. J., & Fagnano, M.
Published in: Language and Speech
Year: 2003
Abstract: This study examines the rate of disfluency in spontaneous speech, focusing on the effects of speaker age, the relationship between speakers, the topic of conversation, and the roles and gender of the speakers. It provides insights into the social and psychological factors influencing the use of fillers in speech.

{"label":"Title: "The role of the lexicon in speech perception"

Authors: Marslen-Wilson, W.
Published in: Psychological Review
Year: 1987
Abstract: This paper explores the role of the mental lexicon in speech perception, which may include understanding how and why fillers are used in human speech. It delves into the cognitive processes involved in speech comprehension.

{"label":"Title: "The phonetics and phonology of some syllabic consonants in Southern British English"

Authors: Nolan, F.
Published in: Journal of the International Phonetic Association
Year: 1992
Abstract: This research focuses on the phonetic and phonological aspects of syllabic consonants in Southern British English, which can provide a deeper understanding of the linguistic characteristics of fillers like "um" and "uh."

{"label":"Title: "The influence of speech rate on the production of disfluency"

Authors: O'Connell, D. C., & Kowal, S.
Published in: Language and Speech
Year: 2005
Abstract: This study investigates how speech rate influences the production of disfluencies, including fillers. It offers insights into the relationship between the speed of speech and the use of fillers.

{"label":"Title: "The relationship between lexical retrieval and segmental and articulatory timing"

Authors: Goldrick, M., & Blumstein, S. E.
Published in: Journal of Memory and Language
Year: 2006
Abstract: This paper examines the connection between the retrieval of words from the mental lexicon and the timing of speech segments and articulation, which may shed light on the cognitive processes behind the use of fillers.

{"label":"Research Area: 
   - Human-machine interface for multiparty open dialogs.
Objective: 
   - To create human simulators using ChatGPT-4 for multiparty dialog interactions, as well as KPI evaluators
   - Write a paper.
Virtual Humans Creation:
   - Defined at a meta level.
   - Personalities, preferences, intolerances, and personal vitae generated by LLMs from brief specifications.
Dialog Topic and Structure:
   - Defined at a meta level.
   - Transcribed into a master plan for the dialog by an LLM.
Simulation Process:
   - Each virtual human is simulated by an LLM, converting personality traits into coherent dialog turns.
   - A virtual moderator guides the dialog according to the predefined master plan.
   - Evaluators compute KPIs to evaluate different aspects of the dialog
Analysis Method:
   - Utilizes quantitative and qualitative KPIs measured by another LLM instance.
   - Demonstrates the feasibility of generating realistic human dialog in a multiparty setting.
Potential applications: 
   - testing artificial systems, creating dialog benchmarks, evaluating human-machine dialog interactions.","category":"TextLabels_Size1","alignment":"0 0.5 0 0","alignmentFocus":"0 0.5 0 0","size":"1080 510","key":45,"location":"1510 -5540"},
